title: The uncharacterized gene 1700093K21Rik and flanking regions are correlated with reproductive isolation in the house mouse, Mus musculus
abstract: Reproductive barriers exist between the house mouse subspecies, Mus musculus musculus and M. m. domesticus, members of the Mus musculus species complex, primarily as a result of hybrid male infertility, and a hybrid zone exists where their ranges intersect in Europe. Using single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) diagnostic for the two taxa, the extent of introgression across the genome was previously compared in these hybrid populations. Sixty-nine of 1316 autosomal SNPs exhibited reduced introgression in two hybrid zone transects suggesting maladaptive interactions among certain loci. One of these markers is within a region on chromosome 11 that, in other studies, has been associated with hybrid male sterility of these subspecies. We assessed sequence variation in a 20 Mb region on chromosome 11 flanking this marker, and observed its inclusion within a roughly 150 kb stretch of DNA showing elevated sequence differentiation between the two subspecies. Four genes are associated with this genomic subregion, with two entirely encompassed. One of the two genes, the uncharacterized 1700093K21Rik gene, displays distinguishing features consistent with a potential role in reproductive isolation between these subspecies. Along with its expression specifically within spermatogenic cells, we present various sequence analyses that demonstrate a high rate of molecular evolution of this gene, as well as identify a subspecies amino acid variant resulting in a structural difference. Taken together, the data suggest a role for this gene in reproductive isolation.

abstract.text: Reproductive barriers exist between the house mouse subspecies, Mus musculus musculus and M. m. domesticus, members of the Mus musculus species complex, primarily as a result of hybrid male infertility, and a hybrid zone exists where their ranges intersect in Europe. Using single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) diagnostic for the two taxa, the extent of introgression across the genome was previously compared in these hybrid populations. Sixty-nine of 1316 autosomal SNPs exhibited reduced introgression in two hybrid zone transects suggesting maladaptive interactions among certain loci. One of these markers is within a region on chromosome 11 that, in other studies, has been associated with hybrid male sterility of these subspecies. We assessed sequence variation in a 20 Mb region on chromosome 11 flanking this marker, and observed its inclusion within a roughly 150 kb stretch of DNA showing elevated sequence differentiation between the two subspecies. Four genes are associated with this genomic subregion, with two entirely encompassed. One of the two genes, the uncharacterized 1700093K21Rik gene, displays distinguishing features consistent with a potential role in reproductive isolation between these subspecies. Along with its expression specifically within spermatogenic cells, we present various sequence analyses that demonstrate a high rate of molecular evolution of this gene, as well as identify a subspecies amino acid variant resulting in a structural difference. Taken together, the data suggest a role for this gene in reproductive isolation.

body_text.text: Reproductive barriers contributing to speciation can occur at prezygotic and postzygotic levels (Mayr 1963; Dobzhansky 1970) . Prezygotic isolation may occur by factors such as ecological differences (Jiggins et al. 1996) , seasonal or temporal mating differences (Monteiro et al. 2012) , gametic incompatibilities (Howard and Waring 1991) , and assortative mating as observed between the subspecies Mus musculus musculus and M. m. domesticus (Smadja et al. 2004; Bímová et al. 2005; Vošlajerová Bímová et al. 2011) . Alternatively, mechanisms including hybrid inviability (Allen et al. 1993; Zechner et al. 1996) and the generation of infertile hybrids (Forejt and Ivanyi 1974; Forejt 1996) may occur at the postzygotic level. Of these mechanisms, hybrid male sterility is one of the most intensively studied, with several investigations supporting its role in reproductive isolation between M. m. musculus and M. m. domesticus (Forejt and Ivanyi 1974; Forejt et al. 1991; Forejt 1996; Storchova et al. 2004; Britton-Davidian et al. 2005; Vyskocilová et al. 2009; Mihola et al. 2009; Good et al. 2008a, b; White et al. 2011; Dzur-Gejdosova et al. 2012; Flachs et al. 2012; Bhattacharyya et al. 2013) .

Wherever these two subspecies overlap in Europe, the naturally occurring hybrid populations exhibit evidence of reduced fertility (Britton-Davidian et al. 2005; Albrechtová et al. 2012; Turner et al. 2012 ) and barriers to gene flow (reviewed in Baird and Macholán 2012; Janousek et al. 2012) . In particular, X chromosome-linked genes have more limited movement than autosomes (Tucker et al. 1992 , Dod et al. 1993 Payseur et al. 2004; Macholan et al. 2007; Teeter et al., 2008; Janousek et al. 2012 ) suggesting a major role for the X chromosome in reproductive isolation. This is consistent with laboratory studies implicating the X chromosome as a primary source of hybrid male infertility (Forejt 1996; Oka et al. 2004 Oka et al. , 2007 Good et al. 2008a Good et al. , b, 2010 Vyskocilová et al. 2009) . For example, Mus intersubspecific crosses yielded hybrid males with lower fertility when the mother was M. m. musculus, and the father was M. m. domesticus than in the reciprocal cross. These F 1 s all had the same autosomal genomes but differed in the origin of the sex chromosomes (Britton-Davidian et al. 2005; Storchova et al. 2004; Good et al. 2010; Dzur-Gejdosova et al. 2012) . Additionally, extensive overexpression of X-chromosome genes has been observed in testes of F 1 hybrids having a M. m. musculus maternal line (Good et al. 2010) . Autosomal loci have also been linked to hybrid infertility in these subspecies (Forejt and Ivanyi 1974; Vyskocilová et al. 2009; Good et al. 2010; White et al. 2011; Flachs et al. 2012; Janousek et al. 2012) , as well as in hybrids of M. m. domesticus and M. m. molossinus, which is genetically close to M. m. musculus (Oka et al. 2007) , necessitating further investigations of autosomal genes in reproductive isolation.

Given the assumption that genes with accelerated evolutionary rates are candidate speciation genes (Orr 2005; Crespi and Nosil 2013) , the identification of subspeciesspecific SNPs provides a tool for identifying candidate reproductive isolation genes in the house mouse. Using subspecies-specific SNP markers identified from a catalog of 13,320 SNPs from the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute, Harr (2006a) found differentiation between M. m. musculus and M. m. domesticus to be elevated throughout the X chromosome and for eight regions on autosomes. Although Boursot and Belkhir (2006) suggested that ascertainment bias may have led to many false positive results, Harr (2006b) provided additional support for the potential relevance of some of these markers in reproductive isolation. More recently, the Mouse Diversity Array (Yang et al. 2009) containing 623,124 SNPs spaced approximately one every 4.3 kb across the genome was used to select 1,536 subspecies-specific diagnostic SNPs spaced approximately 2 Mb apart (Wang et al. 2011) . This array was used to localize chromosomal regions of reduced introgression in 1,301 naturally occurring hybrid M. m. musculus 9 M. m. domesticus mice (Janousek et al. 2012) . These authors analyzed mice collected from two transects across the hybrid zone, one from Southern Bavaria and Austria (BV) and the other, 200 km to the north in Bavaria and the Czech Republic (CZ). As anticipated, a high proportion of X-linked markers (29 of 85) demonstrated reduced introgression in both transects. Of 1,316 autosomal SNP markers, 69 (approximately 5 %) demonstrated a similar pattern of reduced introgression (Janousek et al. 2012) .

In this study, we conducted a detailed investigation of sequence surrounding one of the autosomal SNPs, the marker at position 11:23356000 (NCBIM37/mm9) that had demonstrated reduced introgression and therefore a presumptive negative epistatic pattern similar to X-linked SNPs in both the BV and CZ transects ( Fig. 1 ; Janousek et al. 2012) . This genomic area is of particular interest because it is also within a 24 Mb region on chromosome 11 that is associated with a high sperm head anomaly index and with hybrid male sterility based on a genome-wide QTL analysis (Oka et al. 2007) . These authors refer to this candidate hybrid sterility locus, as ''interacting locus with the X chromosome 3'' (ilx3). To delimit a chromosomal region potentially consequential in reproductive isolation, we present comparative sequence analyses of M. m. musculus and M. m. domesticus for the region flanking SNP 11:23356000 using data from various sources. We identified an approximately 150 kb subregion inclusive of this SNP exhibiting an elevated level of sequence differentiation between populations of M. m. musculus and M. m. domesticus. This subregion fully or partially contains four protein-encoding genes. These were assessed for status as candidate reproductive isolation genes based on protein function, tissue-specificity of gene expression, and DNA and amino acid sequence divergence. We determined exceptional features that implicate 1700093K21Rik as a candidate gene with other genes in this region possibly also having a role.

To search for regions of high genetic differentiation between populations of M. m. musculus and M. m. domesticus, we used the Mouse Diversity Array (Yang et al. 2009 (Yang et al. , 2011 to inspect a 20 Mb window of sequence flanking the SNP marker 11:23356000, referred to in this article as 11.0234, that was associated with negative epistasis in a previous hybrid zone analysis (Janousek et al. 2012) . A 100 kb sliding window with 10 kb steps was utilized to compare seven M. m. musculus and nine M. m. domesticus sampled from European populations (Table  S2 -supporting information from Yang et al. 2011) . The average density of SNPs in the genome-wide data set is 16.66 SNPs per 100 kb (SD = 7.53). Thus, the use of a 100 kb sized window should be large enough to make an estimate of genetic differentiation within the region. SNPs with differentially fixed (or nearly fixed) alleles in the two mouse subspecies were identified. For SNPs to be considered as fixed (or nearly fixed), the frequency of an allele in one of the two subspecies must be equal or higher than 0.9 and at the same time equal or lower than 0.1 in the other subspecies. To determine differentiation between the two mouse subspecies, resulting either from selection or from decreased gene flow, we chose a very simple and straightforward metric calculated as the proportion of differentially fixed or nearly fixed alleles between the two subspecies to the total number of SNPs falling within the 100 kb window (number of differentially fixed SNPs/total number of all SNPs). A similar method was used by Harr (2006a) . The differentiation varies from 0 to 1 according to whether there are no differentially fixed SNPs between the two subspecies within a 100 kb window (value 0) to all SNPs being differentially fixed within the 100 kb window (value 1). The 95th and 99th quantiles were determined from the genome-wide distribution of genetic differentiation represented by non-overlapping 100 kb windows.
body_text.section: Computational analysis of a candidate chromosomal region associated with reproductive isolation

body_text.text: The most differentiated genomic subregion within the analyzed 20 Mb window was further investigated for candidate reproductive isolation genes using information provided by the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute (http://www.sanger.ac. uk/resources/mouse/genomes/), (Keane et al. 2011) , Ensembl (http://www.ensembl.org), UCSC Genome Browser (http://www.genome.ucsc.edu/), and NCBI (http://www. ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/). We focused on sequence divergence, protein function and tissue-specific expression. However, features such as gene size, transcript size(s), and possible protein-coding splice variants were also considered.
body_text.section: Search for candidate genes associated with reproductive barriers

body_text.text: Sequence divergence between subspecies was calculated by comparing the wild-derived PWK/PhJ strain of M. m. musculus and the reference sequence derived from the C57BL6/J strain. Ambiguous nucleotides and insertions/ deletions were not included providing a conservative estimate. Calculations were based on variants identified between strains divided by the size of the gene. In addition, we obtained Clines are generated from genotype data collected from 1301 mice in the CZ transect (n = 869) and BV transect (n = 432). The hybrid index corresponds to the proportion of SNPs with M. m. musculus ancestry. The dark and light green shaded regions denote the expected genomic clines (95 % CI) under a null model for the homozygous and heterozygous genotypes, respectively. Solid black and dashed lines denote the genomic clines for individual loci based on multinomial regression models for the homozygous and heterozygous genotypes, respectively. The left graph (top) shows a SNP marker (11.0205) that deviates slightly from the neutral prediction. The center and right graphs (top) show in both the CZ and BV transects, respectively, a SNP marker (11.0234) that deviates strongly from the neutral prediction, highlighting a pattern consistent with maladaptive epistatic interaction. The bottom graph represents the genomic cline of the X-chromosome SNP X.1622 for comparison information on molecular evolution of genes between mouse and rat reference genomes. Protein identity as well as substitution rates of synonymous and non-synonymous changes were retrieved directly from the Ensembl homology database. These features were obtained for all protein-coding genes within the 20 Mb window around the 11.0234 marker. Then, we compared them to 16,464 ''one2one'' orthologs in the manner of the Tsga8 gene analysis performed by Good et al. (2011) . All mouse-rat homology features were retrieved using Ensembl API programmatic interface.
body_text.section: Search for candidate genes associated with reproductive barriers

body_text.text: The uncharacterized 1700093K21Rik gene had features that warranted additional evaluation (see results). To further validate subspecies-specific differentiation of the 1700093K21Rik gene, we analyzed transcriptome data from testes for up to eight M. m. domesticus wild-derived inbred strains and up to seven M. m. musculus wild-derived inbred strains, along with M. m. castaneus, M. caroli, and M. spretus (Phifer-Rixey et al. unpublished data), in association with consensus genomic sequences from the WSB/EiJ and PWK/ PhJ, both wild-derived strains of M. m. domesticus and M. m. musculus, respectively, and M. spretus from the Wellcome Trust Sanger database. Additional support of the involvement of the 1700093K21Rik in reproductive isolation could include an impact of an amino acid replacement on the structure or function of the protein. Therefore, we performed GlobPlots (GlobPlot 2.3; globplot.embl.de) developed by Linding et al. (2003) , to predict intrinsic protein disorder and globularity using amino acid sequence data. The GlobPlot includes an overlay of the simple modular architectural research tool (SMART) that applies a structural context analysis of predicted disordered segments automatically identifying and annotating domains based on the Pfam database of protein domain families. Since the transcriptome data identified at least one non-synonymous variant between subspecies leading to a differentially charged amino acid, then this analysis has the potential to determine a potential functional impact on the protein.

Population differentiation analysis of a 20 Mb region flanking the 11.0234 SNP marker Based on inspection of 20 Mb of sequence containing 113 genes ( Supplementary Table 1 ) flanking SNP marker 11.0234, roughly twenty peaks were identified that surpassed the 95th quantile based on the genome-wide distribution of differentiation between the two house mouse subspecies, however, only four peaks surpassed the 99th quantile ( Fig. 2a ). Among them is a peak encompassing the 11.0234 SNP. It exhibits the greatest height and width among neighboring peaks, indicating extensive divergence between the subspecies. In addition, the 11.0234 SNP located in this region is the only SNP exhibiting reduced introgression in two independently sampled transects based on a previous genomic cline analysis (Janousek et al. 2012) . The neighboring SNP, 11.0275, was also found to be in a region of high differentiation. It was inferred to be under negative epistasis but in one transect only and, thus, could be a false positive resulting from linkage disequilibrium. We, therefore, concentrated the analysis to 2 Mb of DNA flanking the 11.0234 SNP (Fig. 2b) . Between two subregions that demonstrated differentiation in the 99th quantile within this 2 Mb region (Fig. 2b) , a stretch of roughly 150 kb of DNA showed the greatest differentiation between the subspecies. This subregion contains four genes, with two, Ahsa2 and 1700093K21Rik, housed entirely within the subregion and two, Usp34 and 0610010F05Rik, only partially contained within the subregion (Fig. 2b) . The second subregion located further from the marker does not contain any genes.

We assessed various features of these four genes for consideration as candidates in reproductive isolation and included three neighboring genes (Pex13 and Pus10, Xpo1), with the latter gene within a 95th quantile peak, for comparison ( Fig. 2b; Table 1 ). Based on sequence comparisons between PWK/PhJ, a predominantly M. m. musculus strain and C57Bl6/J, a predominantly M. m. domesticus strain, we compared nucleotide sequence divergence for the seven protein-encoding genes (Table 1) . Removing ambiguous positions and indels, estimates for divergence ranged from 0.27 % for Usp34 to 1.15 % for 1700093K21Rik. The 1.15 % subspecies divergence is relatively high considering the average divergence of genetic loci analyzed between M. m. musculus and M. m. domesticus is 0.54 % (Geraldes et al. 2008) . The Pus10 gene also has a relatively high level of divergence (0.93 %), although this may be the result of the transcript only representing roughly 5 % of the gene sequence. Five genes showed a non-synonymous (amino acid replacement) variant between subspecies (Table 1) . Pex13 contained an ambiguous variant in PWK/PhJ that would yield a non-synonymous substitution. Among these findings, the amino acid replacements with the most impact would likely be the polar negative to non-polar neutral change in 1700093K21Rik, and the polar neutral to polar negative change in 0610010F05Rik. In addition, changes in regulatory variants such as in the 5 0 untranslated region (UTR) or 3 0 UTR of the transcript (observed in six of the seven analyzed genes), or splice variants may be contributing factors for the association of genes with reproductive barriers (Table 1) .
body_text.section: Divergence, function, and expression of genes within and adjacent to the 150 Kb subregion

body_text.text: A comparison of amino acid sequence identity and rate of molecular evolution of the seven genes in and around the 150 kb stretch of DNA between mouse and rat demonstrated that 1700093K21Rik is the most rapidly evolving among them ( Fig. 3 and Supplementary Table 1 ). This finding is even more striking when compared to the genome-wide distribution of protein identity and rate of molecular evolution between mouse and rat (Fig. 3) . Interestingly, the 1700093K21Rik gene is the most rapidly evolving genes within the entire 20 Mb window.
body_text.section: Divergence, function, and expression of genes within and adjacent to the 150 Kb subregion

body_text.text: To further elucidate which gene may be a candidate for reproductive isolation, we directed our attention to the genes that are highly or specifically expressed in the testis. Usp34 and Pex13 have been shown to have relatively high levels of expression in the testes in contrast to other tissues. However, microarray analysis on various DNA chips presented in the University of California Santa Cruz Genome Browser (http:// genome.ucsc.edu/cgibin/hgGene?hgg_gene=uc007ieu.2&hg g_prot=NP_001177330&hgg_chrom=chr11&hgg_start=232 06894&hgg_end=23390560&hgg_type=knownGene&db= mm9&hgsid=205625401) were inconsistent for these two genes (Table 1) . Although Bjorkman et al. (2002) found Pex13 expression to be relatively high in liver and testes, they also found the gene to have a high level of amino acid conservation when compared to hamster and human, 94 % and 91 %, respectively, consistent with the gene being localized outside the region of the highest divergence (Fig. 2b) .
body_text.section: Divergence, function, and expression of genes within and adjacent to the 150 Kb subregion

body_text.text: The 1700093K21Rik gene is one of only 28 genes isolated by Hong et al. (2005) to be specifically expressed and developmentally regulated in mouse spermatogenic cells. Based on gene ontology, 1700093K21Rik appears to have an actin-binding domain, cytoskeletal anchoring domain, and a dystrophin-associated glycoprotein complex, all suggesting a putative role in the structure and function of the sperm. Therefore, the results of various components of (2012). The blue and red dots indicate a SNP exhibiting reduced introgression in the BV and CZ transects, respectively. The SNP markers on either side of 11.0234 do not exhibit reduced introgression in both transects. We, therefore, focused our analysis on levels of population differentiation for a 2 Mb window flanking the 11.0234 SNP (b). Analyzed genes (Table 1) are marked in blue Table 1 Overview of genes fully or partially contained in the high-diversity DNA segment under analysis (Fig. 2b) this study in conjunction with these previous findings warranted further investigation of 1700093K21Rik as a candidate gene involved in reproductive isolation.
body_text.section: Divergence, function, and expression of genes within and adjacent to the 150 Kb subregion

body_text.text: Further detailed sequence analysis of the uncharacterized 1700093K21Rik gene as a candidate for reproductive isolation
body_text.section: Divergence, function, and expression of genes within and adjacent to the 150 Kb subregion

body_text.text: To verify fixed variants within the expressed sequences of the 1700093K21Rik gene, we utilized a transcriptome analysis based on sequences of RT-PCR products of testes RNA (Phifer-Rixey et al. unpublished) in conjunction with the genomic data from the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute. The combined sequence data (Fig. 4) reveal a fixed variant within the 5 0 UTR region (position 2011) between the subspecies. An additional variant identified within the 5 0 UTR (position 1274) may be fixed between subspecies, although transcriptome data are missing from some of the strains at this position (Fig. 4) . One variant (position 3034) was identified in the coding region with data available for all but the M. m. musculus MBT strain. Excluding the poorly characterized BID strain (Voolstra et al. 2007 ) from the analysis, this variant is a fixed replacement substitution, a change from a valine in M. m. domesticus and M. m. castaneus, as well as within the outgroups M. caroli and M. spretus, to glutamic acid in M. m. musculus. This alteration results in a change from a non-polar hydrophobic amino acid at position 57, of the 196 amino acid polypeptide, to an amino acid that has a negative charge. As a result, it likely generates a structural and/or functional change. An amino acid sequence analysis using the GlobPlot program (Linding et al. 2003) from the ExPASY Proteomics server, which recognizes short linear peptide motifs within disordered (non-globular) polypeptide regions, and putative domains in the ordered globular (GLOBDOM) regions shows a slight but visible difference between M. m. domesticus and M. m. musculus in the curve at positon 57 (Fig. 5) . The SMART/ Pfam overlay identified a transmembrane domain within the ordered (downhill curve) region of the 1700093K21Rik protein in M.m domesticus (Fig. 5a ) that is absent in M. m. musculus (Fig. 5b) as a result of this distinctive non-synonymous variant.
body_text.section: Divergence, function, and expression of genes within and adjacent to the 150 Kb subregion

body_text.text: We analyzed a genomic region suspected to harbor genes associated with the reproductive barriers to gene flow between M. m. musculus and M. m. domesticus, subspecies which shared a common ancestor approximately 0.35 mya (Geraldes et al. 2011) . Reproductive isolation between these subspecies appears predominantly associated with male infertility of hybrids (Hale et al. 1993; Forejt 1996; Storchova et al. 2004; Good et al. 2008a, b; White et al. 2011; Dzur-Gejdosova et al. 2012; Flachs et al. 2012) , including specific defects in spermatogenesis (Good et al. 2008a (Good et al. , b, 2010 . Although the X chromosome has widely been implicated as the primary contributor to the defects leading to male infertility, including empirical evidence of disruption of X-inactivation (Good et al. 2010) , only a few candidate genes have been identified. Among the most notable are the X-linked Tsga8 gene, which evolves rapidly based on rat and mouse amino acid sequence comparisons and is involved in mouse spermiogenesis (Good et al. 2011) . Autosomal genes have also been associated with reproductive barriers between these subspecies. The most notable is the Prdm9 gene (Forejt and Ivanyi 1974) , an autosomal gene on mouse chromosome 17, which encodes a meiotic histone H3 methyltransferase and is associated with meiotic arrest in hybrid males (Vyskocilová et al. 2009) . Replacing alleles of this gene has been shown to rescue infertility in male hybrids (Mihola et al. 2009; Flachs et al. 2012) . We present a collection of data supporting 1700093K21Rik as an additional autosomal gene associated with reproductive isolation between the Mus musculus subspecies. Several investigations have reported findings that suggest a role in hybrid male sterility for mouse chromosome 11, pinpointing a region on this autosome (Gregorova et al. 2008; Oka et al. 2007; Janousek et al. 2012 ) that warranted further investigation for candidate genes.

The M. m. musculus -M. m. domesticus SNP marker 11.0234 was one of only 5 % of analyzed autosomal SNPs with similar patterns of introgression to contiguous regions of the X chromosome (Janousek et al. 2012) exhibiting putative maladaptive epistasis. Through our detailed analysis of population differentiation between the subspecies commencing with a 20 Mb region (±10 Mb of the 11.0234 SNP) and fine-tuning it to a 2 Mb interval, we found this SNP was contained in the most highly genetically differentiated subregion, an approximately 150 kb segment of DNA.

This approach led to the identification of a candidate reproductive isolation gene, 1700093K21Rik. We identified a combination of noteworthy features that corroborate this role. These features include fixed or nearly fixed nucleotide differences between subspecies, rapid evolutionary rates of both the nucleotide and amino acid sequences of this gene, and proteomic data that show structural changes between the subspecies. Furthermore, associated findings of Hong et al. (2005) indicate this is one of only a few genes specifically expressed in mouse spermatogenic cells with a putative structural function based on in silico analysis. Therefore, the variation of 1700093K21Rik is consistent with the finding of sperm anomalies of F 1 hybrid males (Good et al. 2010) and with F 1 male infertility being a driving force of reproductive isolation between these subspecies (Forejt and Ivanyi 1974; Forejt et al. 1991; Forejt 1996; Storchova et al. 2004; Britton-Davidian et al. 2005; Vyskocilová et al. 2009; Good et al. 2008a, b; Mihola et al. 2009; White et al. 2011) .

Changes in gene expression may also underlie barriers to gene flow by creating hybrids with lower fitness. For example, the loss of imprinting of autosomal genes, which yields biallelic expression, has been observed in interspecies hybrids of Peromyscus (Vrana et al. 1998) and Mus (Shi et al. 2005) . Altered expression of sterility-correlated autosomal genes has been observed in the M. m. musculus 9 M. m. domesticus hybrids (Good et al. 2010) . The Dnmt3a and Brwd1 genes were both significantly underexpressed in sterile male hybrids, and their protein products are involved in spermatogenesis. It is possible that the 5 0 UTR differences of the 1700093K21Rik transcript between M. m. musculus and M. m. domesticus alters the posttranscriptional regulation of the gene, perhaps in RNA stability or translation regulation. The varied regulation may be associated with negative epistasis and correlated with reduced introgression of the 11.0234 SNP marker observed in the hybrid zone of M. m. musculus and M. m domesticus (Janousek et al. 2012) . Although not having all the distinctive features of 1700093K21Rik, other genes in this region, such as Usp34, may also be associated with reproductive isolation and warrant further investigation.

The analysis of introgression on chromosome 11 covered two additional SNPs, 11.0256 and 11.0294, presumptively supporting negative epistasis in both transects (Janousek et al., 2012) . As such, these are also regions with candidate reproductive isolation genes. However, they show low levels of differentiation between subspecies. These regions may contain reproductive isolation genes that are categorically different than genes associated with sperm competition. Alternatively, they may be false positives, their association with negative epistasis resulting from linkage disequilibrium.

We have presented the use of genomic data such as the mouse diversity array and the mouse strain genome project, each consisting of a dense number of SNPs, in conjunction with additional genomic and proteomic tools as an effective procedure to identify genes potentially associated with reproductive isolation by refining data generated from large-scale genome-wide meta analyses. In this study, several paths of analysis suggest the involvement of the 1700093K21Rik gene in hybrid male sterility between M. m. musculus and M. m. domesticus. This gene is likely to be just one among other genes associated with reproductive isolation between these taxa. The direct mechanistic impact of this gene on reproductive isolation may be directly related to protein structure and function, and/or regulation of expression of the gene at the transcriptional or posttranscriptional level resulting in maladaptive epistatic interactions. Genetic experiments are likely to yield insight into the direct contribution of this gene to hybrid male sterility and reproductive isolation. Population genetic studies may provide evidence for the mode of selection ultimately generating differentiation between subspecies.
D. H.Kass et al.: 1700093K21Rik gene and reproductive isolation in Mus

VJ received support from the Institutional Research Support Grant No. SVV-2013-267 201, the Grant Agency of Charles University in Prague Grant No. 6421/2012 and from the NextGen project No. CZ.1.07/2.3./20.0303. The authors thank Miloš Macholán, Jaroslav Piálek, Michael Nachman, and two anonymous reviewers for their valuable comments on an earlier version of this manuscript. The authors also thank Michael Nachman for providing us transcriptome data prior to publication.

FIGREF0.text: Examples of genomic clines (Gompert and Buerkle, 2009) of SNPs in hybrid populations of M. m. musculus and M. m. domesticus.

FIGREF1.text: Population differentiation between M. m. musculus and M. m. domesticus and comparison to the genome-wide median and 95th and 99th quantiles (gray lines). (a) Levels of differentiation between subspecies for a 20 Mb window surrounding the SNP marker 11.0234. The four tallest peaks surpass the 99th quantile. Vertical red lines represent the location of SNPs used in Janousek et al.

FIGREF2.text: Amino acid sequence divergence (a) and synonymous and non-synonymous substitution rates (b) for seven analyzed genes were compared to 16464 ''one2one'' orthologs between mouse and rat

FIGREF3.text: Analysis of transcriptome data for 17000093K21Rik gene among wild-derived M. m. musculus and M. m. domesticus strains, derived from a large-scale transcriptome project of genes expressed in the testis using an Illumina assay (Phifer-Rixey et al. unpublished). We merged our reads with the Sanger Wellcome Trust Institute database for CAST (M. m. castaneus), WSB (M. m. domesticus), PWK (M. m. musculus), and SPRET (M. spretus). The outgroups are M. caroli and M. spretus. Blank spaces indicate missing data. E exon, C coding sequence, R replacement variant, S synonymous variant

FIGREF4.text: Proteomic analysis of the 17000093K21Rik gene using GlobPlots (ExPasy). The X-axis corresponds to the position of the amino acids of the polypeptide chain. The Y-axis (disorder propensity) measures the lack of regular secondary structure. Uphill regions correspond to predicted motifs in disordered regions (blue boxes), whereas downhill GLOBDOM regions correspond to putative motifs in ordered regions. A non-synonymous substitution identified between M. m. domesticus and M. m. musculus sequence seemingly results in an alteration in a transmembrane domain within the amino acid region indicated by the hatched bar. a M. m. domesticus, b M. m. musculus
